sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying plane
message_1: A rectangular loop of wire with dimensions 50cm x 20cm carries a current of 5A. Calculate the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at a point directly above the center of the loop at a distance of 10cm from the plane of the loop.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at a point directly above the center of the loop, we can use the formula for the magnetic field due to a rectangular loop:

B = (μ₀ * I * a * b) / (4 * π * (a^2 + x^2)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A), I is the current, a and b are the dimensions of the loop, and x is the distance from the plane of the loop.

Given the dimensions of the loop, a = 0.5 m (50 cm) and b = 0.2 m (20 cm). The current I = 5 A, and the distance x = 0.1 m (10 cm).

Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) Tm/A * 5 A * 0.5 m * 0.2 m) / (4 * π * (0.5^2 + 0.1^2)^(3/2))

B = (2π × 10^(-7) T * 0.5 * 0.2) / ((0.5^2 + 0.1^2)^(3/2))

B = (2π × 10^(-7) T * 0.1) / (0.26^(3/2))

B ≈ 7.94 × 10^(-7) T

The magnitude of the magnetic field at the point directly above the center of the loop is approximately 7.94 × 10^(-7) T.

As for the direction of the magnetic field, it can be determined using the right-hand rule. If you point your thumb in the direction of the current in the loop, your fingers will curl in the direction of the magnetic field. Since the current is flowing in a rectangular loop, the magnetic field will be directed out of the plane of the loop at the point directly above the center.
